column2: Though she would not for the world have owned it to her parents, Undine was disappointed in the Fairford dinner.
column3: Though she would not for the world have owned it to her parents, Undine was disappointed in the Fairford dinner.

column2: The house, to begin with, was small and rather shabby.
column3: The house, to begin with, was small and rather shabby.

column2: Undine was too young to take note of culinary details, but she had expected to view the company through a bower of orchids and eat pretty-coloured entrees in ruffled papers. Instead, there was only a low centre-dish of ferns, and plain roasted and broiled meat that one could recognize--as if they'd been dyspeptics on a diet!
column3: Undine was too young to take note of culinary details, but she had expected to view the company through a bower of orchids and eat pretty coloured entrees in ruffled papers. Instead, there was only a low centre dish of ferns, and plain roasted and broiled meat that one could recognize-as if they'd been dyspeptics on a diet!

column2: With all the hints in the Sunday papers, she thought it dull of Mrs. Fairford not to have picked up something newer; and as the evening progressed she began to suspect that it wasn't a real "dinner party," and that they had just asked her in to share what they had when they were alone.
column3: With all the hints in the Sunday papers, she thought it dull of mrs Fairford not to have picked up something newer; and as the evening progressed she began to suspect that it wasn't a real "dinner party," and that they had just asked her in to share what they had when they were alone.

column2: But a glance about the table convinced her that Mrs. Fairford could not have meant to treat her other guests so lightly.
column3: But a glance about the table convinced her that mrs Fairford could not have meant to treat her other guests so lightly.

column2: They were only eight in number, but one was no less a person than young Mrs. Peter Van Degen--the one who had been a Dagonet--and the consideration which this young lady, herself one of the choicest ornaments of the Society Column, displayed toward the rest of the company, convinced Undine that they must be more important than they looked.
column3: They were only eight in number, but one was no less a person than young mrs peter Van Degen-the one who had been a Dagonet-and the consideration which this young lady, herself one of the choicest ornaments of the Society Column, displayed toward the rest of the company, convinced Undine that they must be more important than they looked.

column2: She liked Mrs. Fairford, a small incisive woman, with a big nose and good teeth revealed by frequent smiles.
column3: She liked mrs Fairford, a small incisive woman, with a big nose and good teeth revealed by frequent smiles.

column2: In her dowdy black and antiquated ornaments she was not what Undine would have called "stylish"; but she had a droll kind way which reminded the girl of her father's manner when he was not tired or worried about money.
column3: In her dowdy black and antiquated ornaments she was not what Undine would have called "stylish"; but she had a droll kind way which reminded the girl of her father's manner when he was not tired or worried about money.

column2: She had not expected much of Mr. Fairford, since married men were intrinsically uninteresting, and his baldness and grey moustache seemed naturally to relegate him to the background; but she had looked for some brilliant youths of her own age--in her inmost heart she had looked for Mr. Popple.
column3: She had not expected much of mr Fairford, since married men were intrinsically uninteresting, and his baldness and grey moustache seemed naturally to relegate him to the background; but she had looked for some brilliant youths of her own age-in her inmost heart she had looked for mr Popple.

column2: Undine sat between Mr. Bowen and young Marvell, who struck her as very "sweet" (it was her word for friendliness), but even shyer than at the hotel dance.
column3: Undine sat between mr Bowen and young Marvell, who struck her as very "sweet" (it was her word for friendliness), but even shyer than at the hotel dance.

column2: Mrs. Fairford talked so well that the girl wondered why Mrs. Heeny had found her lacking in conversation.
column3: mrs Fairford talked so well that the girl wondered why mrs Heeny had found her lacking in conversation.

column2: But though Undine thought silent people awkward she was not easily impressed by verbal fluency.
column3: But though Undine thought silent people awkward she was not easily impressed by verbal fluency.

column2: All the ladies in Apex City were more voluble than Mrs. Fairford, and had a larger vocabulary: the difference was that with Mrs. Fairford conversation seemed to be a concert and not a solo.
column3: All the ladies in Apex City were more voluble than mrs Fairford, and had a larger vocabulary: the difference was that with mrs Fairford conversation seemed to be a concert and not a solo.

column2: She took particular pains to give Undine her due part in the performance; but the girl's expansive impulses were always balanced by odd reactions of mistrust, and to-night the latter prevailed.
column3: She took particular pains to give Undine her due part in the performance; but the girl's expansive impulses were always balanced by odd reactions of mistrust, and to night the latter prevailed.

column2: This state of lucidity enabled her to take note of all that was being said.
column3: This state of lucidity enabled her to take note of all that was being said.

column2: Yes--he's doing me, Mrs. Peter Van Degen was saying, in her slightly drawling voice.
column3: Yes-he's doing me, mrs peter Van Degen was saying, in her slightly drawling voice.

column2: He's doing everybody this year, you know--
column3: He's doing everybody this year, you know-

column2: That delightful Popple--he paints so exactly as he talks! the white-haired lady took it up.
column3: That delightful Popple-he paints so exactly as he talks! the white haired lady took it up.

column2: All his portraits seem to proclaim what a gentleman he is, and how he fascinates women!	All his portraits seem to proclaim what a gentleman he is, and how he fascinates women!
They're not pictures of Mrs. or Miss So-and-so, but simply of the impression Popple thinks he's made on them."
column3: They're not pictures of mrs or Miss So and so, but simply of the impression Popple thinks he's made on them."

column2: Mrs. Fairford smiled.
column3: mrs Fairford smiled.

column2: Something in her tone made all Undine's perceptions bristle, and she strained her ears for the answer.
column3: Something in her tone made all Undine's perceptions bristle, and she strained her ears for the answer.

column2: I think he'll do you capitally--you must let me come and see some day soon. Marvell's tone was always so light, so unemphasized, that she could not be sure of its being as indifferent as it sounded.
column3: I think he'll do you capitally-you must let me come and see some day soon. Marvell's tone was always so light, so unemphasized, that she could not be sure of its being as indifferent as it sounded.

column2: She looked down at the fruit on her plate and shot a side-glance through her lashes at Mrs. Peter Van Degen.
column3: She looked down at the fruit on her plate and shot a side glance through her lashes at mrs peter Van Degen.

column2: Mrs. Van Degen was neither beautiful nor imposing: just a dark girlish-looking creature with plaintive eyes and a fidgety frequent laugh.
column3: mrs Van Degen was neither beautiful nor imposing: just a dark girlish looking creature with plaintive eyes and a fidgety frequent laugh.

column2: But she was more elaborately dressed and jewelled than the other ladies, and her elegance and her restlessness made her seem less alien to Undine.
column3: But she was more elaborately dressed and jewelled than the other ladies, and her elegance and her restlessness made her seem less alien to Undine.

column2: She had turned on Marvell a gaze at once pleading and possessive; but whether betokening merely an inherited intimacy (Undine had noticed that they were all more or less cousins) or a more personal feeling, her observer was unable to decide; just as the tone of the young man's reply might have expressed the open avowal of good-fellowship or the disguise of a different sentiment.
column3: She had turned on Marvell a gaze at once pleading and possessive; but whether betokening merely an inherited intimacy (Undine had noticed that they were all more or less cousins) or a more personal feeling, her observer was unable to decide; just as the tone of the young man's reply might have expressed the open avowal of good fellowship or the disguise of a different sentiment.

column2: Yet in the drawing-room, with the ladies, where Mrs. Fairford came and sat by her, the spirit of caution once more prevailed.
column3: Yet in the drawing room, with the ladies, where mrs Fairford came and sat by her, the spirit of caution once more prevailed.

column2: She wanted to be noticed but she dreaded to be patronized, and here again her hostess's gradations of tone were confusing.
column3: She wanted to be noticed but she dreaded to be patronized, and here again her hostess's gradations of tone were confusing.

column2: Undine did not even know that there were any pictures to be seen, much less that "people" went to see them; and she had read no new book but "When The Kissing Had to Stop," of which Mrs. Fairford seemed not to have heard.
column3: Undine did not even know that there were any pictures to be seen, much less that "people" went to see them; and she had read no new book but "When The Kissing Had to Stop," of which mrs Fairford seemed not to have heard.

column2: The conversation was revived for a moment by her recalling that she had seen Sarah Bernhard in a play she called "Leg-long," and another which she pronounced "Fade"; but even this did not carry them far, as she had forgotten what both plays were about and had found the actress a good deal older than she expected.
column3: The conversation was revived for a moment by her recalling that she had seen Sarah Bernhard in a play she called "Leg long," and another which she pronounced "Fade"; but even this did not carry them far, as she had forgotten what both plays were about and had found the actress a good deal older than she expected.

column2: This discovery resulted in her holding her vivid head very high, and answering "I couldn't really say," or "Is that so?" to all Mr. Fairford's ventures; and as these were neither numerous nor striking it was a relief to both when the rising of the elderly lady gave the signal for departure.
column3: This discovery resulted in her holding her vivid head very high, and answering "I couldn't really say," or "Is that so?" to all mr Fairford's ventures; and as these were neither numerous nor striking it was a relief to both when the rising of the elderly lady gave the signal for departure.

column2: In the hall, where young Marvell had managed to precede her.
column3: In the hall, where young Marvell had managed to precede her.

column2: Undine found Mrs. Van Degen putting on her cloak.
column3: Undine found mrs Van Degen putting on her cloak.

column2: Ralphie, dear, you'll come to the opera with me on Friday?	Ralphie, dear, you'll come to the opera with me on Friday?
We'll dine together first--Peter's got a club dinner." They exchanged what seemed a smile of intelligence, and Undine heard the young man accept.
column3: We'll dine together first-Peter's got a club dinner." They exchanged what seemed a smile of intelligence, and Undine heard the young man accept.

column2: Then Mrs. Van Degen turned to her.
column3: Then mrs Van Degen turned to her.

column2: Good-bye, Miss Spragg.	Good bye, Miss Spragg.
I hope you'll come--"
column3: I hope you'll come-"

column2: --TO DINE WITH ME TOO? That must be what she was going to say, and Undine's heart gave a bound.
column3: --TO DINE WITH ME TOO? That must be what she was going to say, and Undine's heart gave a bound.

column2: --to see me some afternoon, Mrs. Van Degen ended, going down the steps to her motor, at the door of which a much-furred footman waited with more furs on his arm.
column3: --to see me some afternoon, mrs Van Degen ended, going down the steps to her motor, at the door of which a much furred footman waited with more furs on his arm.

column2: Undine's face burned as she turned to receive her cloak.
column3: Undine's face burned as she turned to receive her cloak.

column2: He was going to "escort" her home, of course!
column3: He was going to "escort" her home, of course!
